Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: 3 infant doses at months 2, 4, and 6 + booster around year 6
Notes:
Truelove et al. estimate this as the total vaccine effectiveness against infection, but note this is likely due to reduction of shedding/infectiousness.
Though evidence is very limited, there appears to be no protection against acquisition of infection (see single 1972 study by Miller et al.)
Sources used:
Truelove SA, Keegan LT, Moss WJ, Chaisson LH, Macher E, Azman AS, Lessler J. Clinical and Epidemiological Aspects of Diphtheria: A Systematic Review and Pooled Analysis. Clin Infect Dis. 2020 Jun 24;71(1):89-97. doi: 10.1093/cid/ciz808. PMID: 31425581; PMCID: PMC7312233.
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/504408

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against severe disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: 3 infant doses at months 2, 4, and 6 + booster around year 6
Notes: defined as local+systemic symptoms+a major complication. Higher against mortality 93% (90-96)
Sources used: Truelove SA, Keegan LT, Moss WJ, Chaisson LH, Macher E, Azman AS, Lessler J. Clinical and Epidemiological Aspects of Diphtheria: A Systematic Review and Pooled Analysis. Clin Infect Dis. 2020 Jun 24;71(1):89-97. doi: 10.1093/cid/ciz808. PMID: 31425581; PMCID: PMC7312233.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes: Years of full clinical immunity protection (0.1 IU/ml) after 3 doses without booster. Note that Truelove (above) provide a much lower rate of waning. They also report a decline in VE by age 0-4 96%; 5-9 92%;>=20 63%. See suppl fig 5b to get CIs.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Notes: total vaccine effectiveness including effect on susceptibility to infection and on infectiousness to others. Choi et al. report 80% in England and Wales.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against severe disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Notes: Effectiveness in the first 5 years of life against WHO standard case definition of severe pertussis. Effectiveness among adults is not well documented. Effectiveness tends to go up as clinical endpoint becomes more severe.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes: Range. Values approximated from Fig 4 in Choi et al. paper.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Notes: Cochrane review; 2 doses (unspecified timing). 3 cohort studies only.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against severe disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Notes: VE based on sys review of observational epi studies measles cases (for MVC1&MCV2, n=8 studies) (global Eng lang only)
Sources used: Uzicanin, Amra, and Laura Zimmerman. “Field Effectiveness of Live Attenuated Measles-Containing Vaccines: A Review of Published Literature.” The Journal of Infectious Diseases 204 (2011): S133–48. http://www.jstor.org/stable/41230455

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes: Estimated proportion no longer protected per year  based on pooled studies (n=12) of antibody waning
Sources used: Schenk J, Abrams S, Theeten H, Van Damme P, Beutels P, Hens N. Immunogenicity and persistence of trivalent measles, mumps, and rubella vaccines: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2021 Feb;21(2):286-295. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30442-4. Epub 2020 Sep 1. PMID: 32888410; PMCID: PMC9665966

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: IPV: 2 infant doses at months 1 and 2; OPV: 3 infant doses at months 2, 4, and 6 with boosters at 18mths and around year 6
Other specifications: In Gaza, OPV is combined with IPV
Notes:
Macklin et al: % gaining intestinal immunity as a proxy of infectiousness, for 3bOPV-2IPV schedule.
Effect is driven by OPV.
o'Ryan show non-inferiority of combined OPV-IPV schedule vs IPV in terms of immunogenicity.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: two bOPV doses for all children under 5y
Notes: Macklin et al: % gaining intestinal immunity as a proxy of infectiousness, for 3bOPV schedule.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against severe disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: IPV: 2 infant doses at months 1 and 2; OPV: 3 infant doses at months 2, 4, and 6 with boosters at 18mths and around year 6
Other specifications: In Gaza, OPV is combined with IPV
Notes: Paralitic poliomyelitis. Grassly: 2 doses of IPV would provide about 80% protection. Effect is driven by IPV, and there is evidence that the combined schedule is non-inferior to IPV alone. Consistent with WHO/SAGE review of older literature. Lower-upper bounds estimated by reviewer based on values in WHO/SAGE review.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Other specifications: In Gaza, OPV is combined with IPV
Notes:
Very limited data, so figures are assumed (conversely, one may assume zero waning).
Swartz: zero waning in 5 years after IPV-OPV series in Israel. Ma and Gao papers: full protection for at least 10y post booster.

Infectious disease / vaccine: Haemophilus influenzae type B (as part of pentavalent vaccine)
Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Notes: Adegbola (Gambia). Consistent with Murphy (81%).

Infectious disease / vaccine: Haemophilus influenzae type B (as part of pentavalent vaccine)
Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against pneumonia (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Notes: Against radiologically confirmed pneumonia. Includes RCTs and observational studies.

Infectious disease / vaccine: Haemophilus influenzae type B (as part of pentavalent vaccine)
Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against meningitis or other invasive disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Notes: Effect on Hib meningitis mortality, assumed to be a reasonable proxy of severe disease. Very consistent with Griffiths et al.'s estimate for invasive disease.

Infectious disease / vaccine: Haemophilus influenzae type B (as part of pentavalent vaccine)
Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes:
Little evidence, but very limited waning at least in the first 10 years. Estimated values.
Silfverdal: About 90% still had protective levels of Abs at 5y of age.
Hammitt: with time, naturally acquired Abs are replaced by vaccine-acuired Abs, with no loss in immunity.
Hallander: Very limited waning in first 10y.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: 2 infant doses at months 2, 4; dose 3 at month 12
Notes: Table 1 of Flasche et al. Broadly consistent with Figures 2-3, Fleming-Dutra et al. review. Note this is in toddlers, but not too different from infants according to Fleming-Dutra et al.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against pneumonia (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: 2 infant doses at months 2, 4; dose 3 at month 12
Notes:
Table 2 of citation: Cutts et al. trial, evaluating CXR pneumonia among children 6-51 weeks of age, followed for 2 years. Cutts trial also seems consistent with observational studies (Table 4), though the latter include indirect effects.
Results are also broadly consistent with review by Reyburn et al., though again the latter include indirect effects.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against meningitis or other invasive disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Definition of fully vaccinated in Gaza: 2 infant doses at months 2, 4; dose 3 at month 12
Notes: NOTE: Vaccine-type only IPD. Some IPD may be non-VT. Median of trials ond observational studies (Tables 2-3, Conklin et al.) among general population.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes: Waning of protection against carriage (infection). Rate per year. However, this is with a booster. With the 3+0 schedule, waning appears much faster (Swarthout et al.).

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against infection (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring infection)
Notes: Bennett et al.: household SAR study from Malawi. SAR estimates similar to Ecuador and New Zealand, so perhaps results would not be too unrepresentative of a high-income setting.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Vaccine effectiveness against severe disease (% of fully vaccinated people who are protected against acquiring severe disease)
Notes: Developed' countries, vaccine effectiveness. Table 1 (Lamberti et al.). Effect on hospitalisations due to rotavirus. Children <5yo. Consistent with Hungerford et al. and Clark et al.

Outcome of vaccination (direct/individua: Immunity waning rate per year (1 / mean duration of functional vaccine protection against infection and/or disease)
Notes: From Haber et al.: Waning under three waning models: moderate, low, severe. Transformed from monthly rate to yearly rate via risk. Fairly consistent with Clark et al.
